question: Maybe you should have tried cutting him some slack. What's that? Gimme a break. Open it. At ease, Rambo. Wait outside. Hello, John.
answer: Colonel.

question: Mind if I sit down? I hear you're not enjoying it here.
answer: I could take it or leave it.

question: Seems like I'm always pulling you out of some goddamn toilet or other, doesn't it?
answer: Am I out of here?

question: That depends on you. Christ, look at you. I give you this easy duty until I can get you an assignment... all you have to do is eat ice cream and watch soap operas... and you have to make it Rambo's last stand.
answer: There were treating me like a headcase.

question: Hard to believe. You shoot up one little town in Oregon with a fifty caliber machine gun... one little dogpatch town... and everybody figures your wrapper's broken. No sense of humor. What did you expect? An engraved plague from the chamber of commerce?
answer: In 'Nam I flew gunships. Million dollar equipment. Back here nobody trusts me to park cars. I keep thinking it's going to be okay... but I've been out six years and it's not okay. Sometimes I feel like I'm coming right out of my skin.

question: This your stuff?
answer: That's it. My life.

question: Hardcore outfit. The best I ever trained.
answer: Those men are all dead.

question: You're not. Congressional Medal of Honor.
answer: Yeah. Big time.

question: Plus, what else? Two Silver Stars, four Bronze Stars, two Soldier's Medals, four Vietnamese Crosses of Gallantry and... uh, a handful of Purple Hearts.
answer: Five. I never wanted that stuff.

question: What did you want?
answer: I just wanted... I don't know... after all that... I just wanted one person, one person, to come up to me and say "you did good, John." And mean it. That's all. After all that.

question: Good to meet you, Rambo. How are you?
answer: You a spook?

question: That's right. CIA Special Operations Division.
answer: I don't work with spooks. Not after that op in Cambodia.

question: I'm authorized to get you out of here. I thought that's what you wanted.
answer: What's the job?

question: Classic special forces op... hit fast... in and out. Two men. Two days.
answer: Why me?

question: We like you. At least the computer at Langley likes you. Pulled your file because of various factors. Service record. Area familiarity.
answer: Where?

question: Not yet.
answer: I'm not jumping blind.

question: This is your mission packet... Memorize it here. It doesn't leave this room. The twenty-four hundred American servicemen missing in action in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia are officially listed "Presumed Killed." Certainly most of them are. But reports keep filtering in. Sightings by refugees. Nothing verified. Finally, we feel we've got enough to proceed on. Memo E-7 on top will cover the details. An abandoned Vietnamese Army base in the North-central highlands may have a compound used as an internment camp. As you can see the intelligence is soft. These LANDSAT photos show huts... barracks. It could be anything.
answer: What's the plan?

question: This operation is in two phases. Recon and rescue. You are phase one. Your two-man team will probe the site, confirm the presence of American POWs, if any, make photographic and tactical observations, then proceed to the extraction point without engaging the enemy.
answer: We don't try to pull out any of our guys if we find them?

question: Negative. Absolutely not. The phase two assault team will get them out.
answer: We just take pictures?

question: Sorry old buddy, I saw it first. I kinda got an important date. No problem. We'll share it. Get your tail in there, sweet thing. Indra Hotel. And don't take the scenic route, Smiley... I know my way around this burg. Comprende?
answer: Same place for me.

question: Ah, you fair flower of the Orient. She thinks everything I say is funny. Don't you, Angel-pie? Man, Thai women are the best. Got the kinda legs I like... feet at one end and pussy at the other. You don't say a helluva lot, do you, pal? You speak English?
answer: Sometimes.

question: Sweet thing, there's nothin' I'd like more than to wugga-wugga with you for a week, but tonight's all we got. See, I'm on this secret mission, and tomorrow mornin' I head out to...
answer: That's enough, Brewer.

question: How long before you're fully on line?
answer: Couple hours. Let me buy you a coffee.

question: You think they'll find any?
answer: POWs? I don't know. But either way it'll get that subcommittee off our necks. Cream?

question: Black. No sugar.
answer: The League of Families leans on Congress. Then they lean on us. Like we don't have enough to worry about in a dozen dirtwater countries. Damnit!

question: Again.
answer: Insertion. Call in to base camp by TRANSAT. Proceed to point Tango November for rendezvous with our ground contact. Indigenous agent. Co Phuong Bao. We've been over this three times.

question: You stopped.
answer: Co Phuong Bao. The guide takes us twelve klicks upriver to target at Ban... at Ban... Bo Peep. Shit!

question: Start over.
answer: ... to target at Ban Kia Na. We probe the site...

question: Ninety.
answer: ... then proceed downriver to extraction at point Echo Delta. Doyle takes us out by helicopter, we all live happily ever after and that's the last time, Rambo! I swear to Christ.

question: One hundred.
answer: Gettin' old, huh?

question: Yeah. Second set. Let's go.
answer: Transponder-satellite relay. The signal's coded into infrared pulses, picked up by the spy satellite, bounced to the ground station in Okinawa and relayed to the hut... No radio source. Nothing for the bad guys to triangulate on.

question: Show me how it operates.
answer: That's what I'm here for.

question: Show me in case you get zapped as soon as we land.
answer: We're leaving tonight, not in a week. Alright. Alright.

question: I think he means it.
answer: Crazy fucker.

question: Well, son. You got that right. Anybody ever tell you about that guy?
answer: What about him?

question: What do you call that?
answer: Modified M-16 A2 and over-under M-79 grenade launcher, with Sionics sound suppressor, Tracor starlight scope and LAC/R-100 Laser sighting system.

question: Batteries not included.
answer: This is state-of-the-art firepower.

question: What's this?
answer: AC-System 'Big-Ear' telescopic mike with built-in audio processor. Can pull a whisper out of a loud cocktail party at 50 meters.

question: Cocktail party. Uh huh, right. Let's saddle up.
answer: Where's your stuff? That's it? Some C-4, a map and a knife?

question: There's a compass in the handle.
answer: And a beat-to-shit AK? Every twelve-year-old in Nam's got one of those.

question: Exactly.
answer: Uh... this thing's pretty heavy. You got room for it? Just a thought.

question: You wanna know why I stood up for this show?
answer: No.

question: I was in the brig. They gave me a deal. I blew up this Colonel's golf cart with an M-19. He wasn't in it or anything... it was the symbolic value. Seemed like a good idea at the time.
answer: That's a real good reason to wind up in 'Nam.

question: I've seen worse places.
answer: There are no worse places.

question: This place is a trip.
answer: Buddhist monastery. Fifteenth century.

question: Damn! Leeches.
answer: Get used to 'em.

question: You fucking crazy? I need it to burn these things off.
answer: No cigarettes.

question: I had it cupped. Look, Rambo. I've had enough of your bad-ass Indian-scout bullshit. You're years out of date... I'm makin' a career out of teaching you the hardware. As far as I'm concerned you're just along to back me up. And I heard about you... about how twitchy you really are. Kill any civilians lately?
answer: Listen real careful, freshmeat. I don't know why they sent you. Maybe they didn't want to waste a good man. But you screw up once more and I'll kill you myself.

question: University of Saigon. Have Masters Degree in economics. Not use too much now... Communists in charge. You got time... want to eat?
answer: Sure. Whattaya got?

question: Nuac mam.
answer: You really got a Masters Degree?

question: Fermented fish sauce. How do we get upriver?
answer: I have arranged transportation. We meet soon. But I think you to be disappointed.

question: Why's that?
answer: I go up to this camp two months ago. Nobody there. Empty for years.

question: Why would they send us to a deserted camp?
answer: Who cares? Let's just do it and get out. Go have a Jacuzzi and get laid in Bangkok. Know what I mean?

question: We'll check it out.
answer: How come we didn't just drop near the camp... save this hassle?

question: Brewer. Does a jet make noise?
answer: Yeah...

question: What's she saying?
answer: She likes you. Says you're dinky- dau.

question: What's that?
answer: Powerful warrior.

question: Yeah. Dinky-dau, that's me. Hey, Co. You wanna meet Jake the one- eyed snake? These guys look like they'd sell their mothers.
answer: Sometimes they do. They're river pirates. Opium runners.

question: Pirates? No kidding?
answer: Thank you, Captain, for your hospitality. You speak English very well.

question: No, sir... we're already committed. They're in the jungle right now. I say we play the hand through... if they find something we just bury the report later. It's still airtight. Yes, sir. Goddamn it! Now the goddamn satellite shows the camp occupied... some trucks or something. What's up?
answer: Listen, Kirkhill. I'm a bit of a fifth wheel in your setup here... I thought I'd go out with the extraction team tonight. Unless you have an objection.

question: It's not necessary.
answer: I know.

question: That's a pretty hairy ride. Full Colonels are supposed to be above that sort of thing.
answer: I know...

question: My brother captain in ARVN... need papers to go United States, or North Vietnamese will execute. They make deal... I stay here and do work... my brother and my son can go United States.
answer: Your son?

question: Nguyen. He twelve now. Not see him for eight years.
answer: Where's his father?

question: Dead. Killed in war.
answer: Where's Nguyen now? What city?

question: Huntington Beach, California.
answer: It's nice there. He's probably digging every minute. Got a surfboard. Breaking girls' hearts.

question: grips the MAC-11 tightly, releases, grips, releases. Sweat runs into his eyes.
answer: How you doing, Brewer?

question: I need a vacation.
answer: watches from concealment in the foliage. He is invisible with his camo-makeup except for darting eyes. Check the tower with your scope.

question: Nobody home. Wait a minute! Cigarette. What's he here for? slips the telescopic microphone out of his rucksack and clamps it to the side of his scope. Snoring. Five, six guys. Mumbling... Vietnamese. Somebody talking in his sleep. A toilet flushing.
answer: Guard barracks. Take some shots.

question: Breathing. Moaning. Shit!
answer: Bad dreams. Prisoner's barracks. Shoot some.

question: She's making him a pretty good deal. What's that? By the far tower.
answer: It's a guy in a cage.

question: American?
answer: Can't tell. Pretty tall. He's real scrunched up in that thing.

question: Let me see. Roundeye.
answer: Alright. Home run.

question: Torture cage. Can't stand... can't sit... for days. Sometimes weeks.
answer: Bastards. Let's get some shots.

question: That guy's not going to make it.
answer: Nothing we can do, man.

question: I'm getting him out.
answer: What? Are you crazy? We're supposed to take pictures and split. You're gonna blow the whole program.

question: You never been in one of those things.
answer: I suppose you have... It's orders! You remember... when they tell you to do something and then you do it. John Wayne is dead, man.

question: You take pictures and split. I'm going in.
answer: Fuck it. Fuck it. Aw... ke-rist. How we gonna do it?

question: You guys are real... aren't you?
answer: Huh?

question: Sorry, I mean... I talk to people all the time... I know a lot of them aren't there. But this is real, isn't it? You're taking me home now?
answer: That's right, buddy.

question: Well, I caught this cobra, see...
answer: You mean the snake?

question: Yeah. It's not hard once you get the hang of it. In the wrist. Anyway, I did what I always do when I get one...
answer: What's that?

question: I do. But they ain't payin' the rent, Jack.
answer: Stay on your heading, Captain.

question: Sorry, Sir. Can't do it.
answer: That's an order.

question: Have a drink.
answer: Why?

question: You got five hours? I'll tell you about Secretaries of State, and funding committees and diplomatic relations...
answer: Take your time.

question: Look, Colonel... we're all adults here. This is a war. A very quiet, very intense war. People get sacrificed.
answer: Not my people. But you're right... some people do get sacrificed. Now tell me why you pulled the plug.

question: You think I'm some whacko? I like to hurt people? I'm doing a job here. If I knew what's right or wrong I'd be a goddamned priest, right? So I follow directives... I do what I'm told. It's simple. If your boy had done what he was told, there wouldn't be a problem.
answer: Don't dance me, Kirkhill. You'll be walking funny.

question: Look, it was a screw-up, alright? They weren't supposed to find anything. We thought that camp was empty.
answer: This mission was a scam from the word go?

question: Word came down... they wanted an answer. And they knew the answer they wanted
answer: Rambo and Brewer were selected as write-offs.

question: It was clean. Very clean... Rambo was a decorated Vietnam vet, a former POW himself... if he came out and said "No POWs" the sub-committee would buy it. He gets himself caught he's a private citizen, a whacko, acting on his own. If he gets proof, it gets lost somewhere between here and D.C. Airtight. But no... Rambo's gotta be a hero. Thinks he's starring in his own war movie or something. He put me in a corner. No choice.
answer: "Terminate with extreme prejudice."

question: That's a crock. We don't say that. Do you have any idea the shitstorm if he'd gotten back with that guy? If it went public? The White House would have to act through channels. We're talking ransom. Four billion bucks in war reparations to Vietnam to get the others back. That's billion, Colonel. With a "B". For a few guys that've had their brains in a blender for ten years? A pain in the ass to everybody? No way. There's no way.
answer: So there never was a Phase Two rescue team?

question: Of course not. You can't get approval to rescue a kitten from a tree after Tehran.
answer: I understand.

question: Here. Drink.
answer: I understand your position. I understand how a maggot like you can just slide out of a jam on a trail of slime. And call it -- expedience. Expedience!

question: You're out of your depth, Trautman. Way out. I'm acting correctly here. Not you. Not your gung-ho jungle ace. It's over. Walk away.
answer: It's not over. You made one mistake.

question: What that?
answer: Rambo.

question: Are they going to torture us?
answer: Yes.

question: What... whattaya do?
answer: Hope they kill you by mistake.

question: Vinh sends the gawking guards scurrying with strident yells as he follows the two Russians into the room. The Soviets stand in front of Rambo. The shorter of the two, LIEUTENANT COMMANDER YATI PODOVSK, has the slight build and unremarkable features of a bank clerk, though for a man in his forties he is in superb condition. The other, LIEUTENANT PALYUSHIN, is another story. He is a tall broad slab of combat muscle, his black hair cut short as a scrub brush. Thick and functional as state sculpture, his features cannot fill his broad, flat face.
answer: Put him in the chair. Thank you, Captain Vinh. Leave one guard, please. These people are so... vulgar in their approach. I am Lieutenant Commander Podovsk. I do not know who you are. Will you tell me? No? Not even your name? This is a poor beginning for an intimate relationship. By tomorrow or the next day you will tell me things you would not tell a lover. I see you are no stranger to pain. Then of course you must know how senseless it is to resist in the long run. Is it possible you have been among my Vietnamese comrades before? Yes. I think that must be it. Where were you held? Hanoi? Son Tay? I apologize. I'm getting ahead. Sometimes I get too eager. My comrade and I, in our capacity as advisors, have been sent from our center at Cam Ranh Bay to discover from you certain things... for example Of course you won't. But, as a moral man, I felt compelled to ask. This is Lieutenant Palyushin. To him you are a piece of meat. Proceed.

question: An IRON BED FRAME has been brought in and leaned vertically against the wall opposite the door.
answer: I was sent here because of my command of your language. It will be frustrating if we cannot have a nice chat. Very frustrating. Ready? Test please.

question: Rambo slams convulsively against the electric grid formed by the steel bed. His teeth are clenched as if he has tetanus. Rambo hangs from his bonds, heaving and shivering.
answer: Oh, yes. Here is something you might be interested in. A transcript of the conversation between your helicopter pilot and his commander, intercepted and unscrambled by our overworked cryptography staff. Mmm. "Zen Hammer... Slam Dunk." Colorful names. Here we are It seems they intentionally abandoned you on direct orders. There are the people you protect with your silence? With your pain? But you must scream. You must. There is no shame.

question: Hey, Brewer. You okay?
answer: I could use a beer.

question: Your buddy made it out last night. The place went apeshit.
answer: Really? How come he didn't take me?

question: Maybe because you're shot in the leg.
answer: Oh, yeah. Listen, how long do they keep you in this disease hole?

question: More AWACS intercepts. The Russian takes time to translate.
answer: He's giving them a run for their money. Says here they've got two Hueys from Danang. I didn't know those dinks had Hueys.

question: Half their air force is our stuff. Captured.
answer: Typical...

question: Sir, there's something else... a TRANSAT relay. Just came through.
answer: What? stares at the sheet for a long time.

question: Christ. How'd you get here?
answer: Took bus, most of way. I knew you would come here.

question: And how'd you sneak up like that?
answer: Carefully. Don't want to get shot by you. Bad karma. Anyway, you need me.

question: I do?
answer: You think you are... .

question: Invulnerable.
answer: In-vul-nerabo. But you get ass kicked without me.

question: Yeah. We're a pretty good team.
answer: You look like hell. Wounds infected. Come up to the ruins, I have medical kit. You try get across Laos? Get to Thailand?

question: Yeah. Got some business there. What are you gonna do?
answer: Go United States. See Nguyen. Maybe teach economics. Buy Cadillac. Watch "Dynasty."

question: How you going to get there? You can't trust the spooks to pull you out. They'll use you up and throw you away.
answer: I know. I go with you.

question: I couldn't get you in.
answer: Yes you can.

question: How?
answer: As wife.

question: Okay. Done. You got it.
answer: You too easy. You don't feel love, Rambo?

question: Look, Co...
answer: Why you don't feel love? Not allowed? Dead inside, maybe? You make yourself dead already so they can't kill you? In-vulnerabo? Bullshit! Bucu bullshit! I have enough death already. Husband. Mother. Father. Brothers. Death everywhere. You see? A flower like that need good soil to grow. Many time under earth is bones of animal... or person. Killed in jungle. Make soil rich. Grows most beautiful flower. You call orchid. Many deaths in jungle. Vietnamese, V.C., American. Many beautiful flowers.

question: Well, have they got him yet?
answer: Um... actually, no. It looks like he shot down one of their gunships...

question: Christ almighty.
answer: ... and then he, uh... took the other one.

question: What?
answer: He... took it.

question: Gawd, you look awful.
answer: You comin'?

question: Hold your pantyhose. Here, gimme a hand.
answer: Can you handle the door gun?

question: Let's go, De Fravio. Move it!
answer: We got company. You better pull some pitch, buddy.

question: Brewer! You know what that thing's packing?
answer: It's a Soviet MIL MI-24. Probably has 12.7mm nose cannon, heat-seeking rockets and wire guided missiles, plus...
